required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12209 Orientation and training.
(1) An agency shall ensure and document all the following:
(a) That each social service worker and each social service supervisor receives
not less than 16 hours of orientation after initial appointment and before
assumption of assigned duties.
Five of nine new employee records reviewed, and one of one records reviewed
where the employee was promoted to supervisor did not show documentation of
16 hours of orientation for the employee to their respective position prior to
assumption of duties.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record must contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance within a probationary
period or not later than 6 months after the staff member assumes his or her
current responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a written evaluation must be
conducted every 12 months.
Seven of 15 employee records reviewed did not show documentation that the
employee's probationary or annual performance evaluation was completed timely
for the respective employee, per the rule.

Repeat Violation Established:
Interim 2024, CAP approved 3/20/2025.
Renewal 2023, CAP approved 11/20/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation must include a determination and assessment of all
the following:
(b) Family functioning and interrelationships as determined by observation of, and
interviews with, each member of the household and each social service worker
who has had children placed in the home during the last licensing period.
In one of six open foster home records reviewed the foster home's reevaluation
did not show documentation that all household members were interviewed as
required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services worker that has children
placed in the home.
In one of three special evaluation records reviewed, the record did not show
documentation that all workers who had children in the home received a copy of
the reevaluation report.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the child in a foster home, then
both the following must be documented before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up to the time of the change
in placement and the needs that remain to be met.
In two of six closed foster child records reviewed the record did not show
documentation of a summary of services provided during care up to the change
and the needs that remain to be met.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2023, CAP approved 11/20/2023.

CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the child in a foster home, then
both the following must be documented before a change in placement:
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
In two of six closed foster child records reviewed the record did not show
documentation as to whether there were provisions for any continuing services.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2023, CAP approved 11/20/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the child's record before a
change of placement occurs:
(e) Replacement preparation of all relevant parties, including the child or infant,
which includes an explanation as to why the change is necessary.
In one of eight open foster child records reviewed where the child was replaced,
the record did not show documentation of preparation of all parties related to two
replacements for the child.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the child's record before a
change of placement occurs:
(g) Information about the child was shared with the new placement, consistent
with the requirements of R 400.12417.
In two of eight open foster child records reviewed where the child was replaced,
the record did not show documentation that all information about the child was
provided the respective caregiver related to two replacements for one child, and
one caregiver related to a replacement for the second child.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.

(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must, include all the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a greater frequency is
medically indicated:
(i) A comprehensive medical examination, including a behavioral/mental health
and trauma screening, within 30 calendar days from the date the child entered
into an out-of-home placement, regardless of the date of the last physical
examination.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the child's trauma
screening due by 3/8/2025 was completed late on 4/3/2025.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 3/20/2025.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must, include all the following:
(f) A dental re-examination must be obtained at least every 9 months, unless a
greater frequency is indicated.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the child's 9-month
dental exam due by 6/9/2025 was completed late on 9/3/2025.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(2) An agency shall maintain a file documentation from the medical or dental
provider of all medical and dental care received by a foster child.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the child's 2/7/2025
medical was not on documentation from the medical provider.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child and parent or
parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.

Three of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show that all of the
child's updated service plans were completed timely.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2023, CAP approved 11/20/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents and the foster parents in
the development of service plans to enable the parent or parents and foster
parents to understand the plan for the child and the parents' and the foster
parent's role in assisting the agency in carrying out the plan. An agency shall give
a copy to and review the parent-agency treatment plan with the parent or parents
and foster parents. The agency must inform the parent or parents and foster
parent that the information in the parent-agency treatment plan and any other
information about the child and the child's family is confidential.
Seven of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show that all treatment
plans were signed and or were signed timely by all parties.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim 2024, CAP approved 3/20/2024.
Renewal 2023, CAP approved 11/20/2023, cited under FOM 722-8D.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(6) Service plans must be signed by the social services worker and the social
services supervisor.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show that the foster care
supervisor signed the child's April 2025 updated service plan.
CPA Rule 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement to a youth before
placement in independent living.
In one of three independent living youth records reviewed the record did not show
documentation that the youth was provided a copy of the agency's program
statement before placement.

CPA Rule 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living with a copy of the
agency's policies and procedures required by this rule.
In one of three independent living youth records reviewed the record did not show
documentation that the youth was provided a copy of the agency's policy and
procedures before placement.
CPA Rule 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
(2) All the following must be in the case record before a youth is placed in
independent living:
(a) How the youth meets the eligibility requirements for the specific program the
youth is being placed into.
One of three open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of how the youth met the eligibility requirements for the program.
CPA Rule 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
(2) All the following must be in the case record before a youth is placed in
independent living:
(f) Proof that financial support to meet the youth's housing, clothing, food, and
miscellaneous expenses is available.
One of three open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of initial proof of financial support to meet the youth's needs.
CPA Rule 400.12507 Medical, dental and mental health care.
(1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent living receives any
needed medical, dental, and mental health care as required in R 400.12413.
Medical, dental, and mental health care provided must be documented in the
youth's record.
One of three independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of the youth dental that was due by 6/3/2025 per last one dated
9/3/2024.

CPA Rule 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record must contain all the following information and documentation,
which must be recorded within 30 calendar days after placement in independent
living and updated at least once every 90 calendar days:
(o) Service plans as required in R 400.12419 and R 400.12420. If the youth has
biological children, the service plan must address the living arrangement for the
child or children, visitation/parenting time with the youth's biological children or a
clear explanation why this is not possible or appropriate.
In two of three independent living youth records reviewed the record showed that
not all treatment plans were signed by all parties; and that not each service plan
was signed by the worker and or the supervisor. Additionally, one of these
records showed the youth's April 2025 update service plans was completed six
days late.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim 2024, CAP approved 3/20/25.
Renewal 2023, CAP approved 11/20/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement.
(2) The agreement must be signed and dated by the youth and the social service
worker. The agreement must be reviewed with the youth at least once every 90
calendar days and a copy provided to the youth.
One of three independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of a November 2024 or February or May 2025 independent living
agreement.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim 2024, CAP approved 3/20/2025.
CPA Rule 400.12607 Agency recommendation.
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption with a signed and dated
copy of the evaluation and recommendation upon its completion.
Two of four adoptive family assessment records reviewed showed the family’s
adoption evaluation was not provided to the family upon its completion.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:.
• R400.12419(1)h) Initial service plans & R400.12420(1)(g) Updated service
plans: The agency was apprised it shall consistently document a behavioral
support specific for the child notwithstanding the child’s age.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• R400.12510(1) Independent living agreement: The agency was advised
ensuring that its staff consistently utilizes the correct independent living
agreement which documents the youth’s location, their requirement to work or
be in school and meeting with the worker in the placement at least monthly,
may aid it in showing continual compliance with the rule.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were two incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period:
The first incident related to an allegation that the foster child was hit on the butt by
the foster mother after the foster child called her sibling an idiot and the “B” word.
During the investigation the foster parent admitted to hitting the child, though she did
not recall the circumstances. The foster home was found in violation of the behavior
management rule. A corrective action plan was developed with the foster parent that
included: De-escalation techniques for working with children who display physically
aggressive behaviors; and positive discipline for toddlers. The agency adhered to all
licensing requirements and timeframes related to this special evaluation.
The second incident related to allegations that the foster parent whooped the child
with a belt when he is bad. During the investigation the child and another child in the
home reported the allegation to be true; and the foster parent admitted to
threatening the child. The foster parent reported issuing out threats to the children by
saying she was going to get their butt, or was going to whoop their butt, when they
would not listen. The foster home was found in violation of the behavior
management rule. A corrective action plan was developed with the foster parent that
included training: Get Results with Better Conversations Trauma & Trauma Informed
Care; Behavioral Challenges in Foster Care, and How to Handle Compassion
Fatigue & Prevent Burnout. The agency adhered to all licensing requirements and
timeframes related to this special evaluation.

Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan during this
licensing period. The corrective action plan related to its 2024 Interim inspection
where it received 16 rule violations; 2 of which were repeat violations. During this
2025 Renewal inspection the agency received 22 rule violations. Six of the 22
violations are repeat violations. Four of the 6 repeat violations are from 2024. Of
these 4 repeat violations from 2024, the number of individual cases cited remained
the same for one of them. For the other 3 repeat violations, the number of
individual cases cited increased: R400.212(3)(a) related to personnel record, the
number of individual cases cited when from 1 of 16 to 7 of 15. R400.418(1)(5)
related to Development of service plans, the number of individual cases cited
when from 3 of 8 to 7 of 8. R400.12509(3)(o) the number of individual cases cited
when from 1 of 3 to 2 of 3.
The agency contributed to its increase in rule violations and increase in the
number of individual cases cited to its staff turnover and poor documentation
which the agency reported it is working to improve. Notwithstanding the rule
violation increases, and agency changes, the agency implemented all action steps
within its 2024 Interim inspection CAP. Amongst the agency’s goals moving
forward are to bringing greater rule compliance and stabilizing its staff.
It is also worth noting that the agency terminated its adoption contract with the
department in September 2025.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted a chief administrator's report dated 10/15/2025 which
denoted violations identified in its 2024 Interim inspection. The chief administrator
reported hiring and training of new staff has continued to be a barrier to timely task
completions; and that new staff expressed not feeling they are equipped to
independently do the job following the department’s child welfare institute training.
Additionally, the agency reported staff have missed some key performance
indicators (KPI) due to staffing issues; but it experienced a slight uptick in various
areas in the recent reporting period due to greater supervisory oversight and
follow-up. Based on concerns related to compliance, the agency has instituted
mandatory monthly CAP compliance meetings; and the chief administrator
reported supervisory monitoring, and documentation is being changed to better
illustrate discussions. As for areas of strength, the agency indicated, it requires
case contacts to be entered into MISACWIS within the first 2 weeks of the month.
This has resulted in improved compliance, specifically with sibling visits, in that the
agency averaged 90% compliance throughout this report period. The agency also
reported utilizing outlooks to send CAP compliance reminders to supervisors
which helped with accountability of their assigned data. The agency reported
moving forward all efforts will be put forth to improve its compliances across all
areas.

Financial Overview
The agency submitted a 2025 annual budget and 9/30/2025 independent financial
audit, which upon review did not show any discernable financial concerns.
Staff Interviews
In addition to my discussion with the chief administrator, Licensing
Director/Supervisor and foster care supervisor, during the entrance conference, I
interviewed two foster care workers, a licensing worker and one supervisor. The
staff interviewed reported feeling supported by their supervisor, and the owner of
the agency, as well as co-workers. They reported strengths for the agency such
as good communications, the chief administrator’s support and supervision;
teamwork; and the agency’s efforts to hire good staff. Area for improvement were
indicated as need for staff retention, better grooming of staff to effectively do their
jobs, hiring a program manager, more training for staff, hands on assistance
related to how to do a task, the agency gaining greater realization and attention to
the fact that staff stress and burn out effects staff productivity, staff consistency,
and an increase in salaries and benefits.
Description of Agency Walk Through
During my walk through at the agency's facility no safety concerns were observed.
The agency appears to have sufficient space and equipment for its employees;
and case records were securely stored.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety concerns identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
